Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Solid-State Devices for Electronics, Photonics, and Magnetics Technology

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration: Micro and nanofabrication of solid-state devices are rapidly becoming the key drivers of interdisciplinary research in emerging fields such as nanoelectronics, nanophotonics, nanomechanics, nanophysics, and biotechnology. Such technology is a critical component of modern economic development, and leadership in research on devices for electronics, photonics, and magnetics is a key to sustained US economic competitiveness. One of the greatest challenges in maintaining that leadership is the limited number of undergraduates from US engineering programs who pursue graduate studies in solid-state devices, especially those from underrepresented groups. This REU site the Summer Undergraduate Research Experience in Solid-State Devices for Electronics, Photonics, and Magnetics Technology ("the SURE program")is established to address this need. The SURE program will provide an average of ten students per summer the opportunity to pursue ten weeks of faculty-directed research. The primary goal is to provide each participant with a scientifically rigorous, intellectually demanding research experience within a highly collegial environment of collaboration with faculty and other students, expert guidance in non-technical aspects of professional development, and frequent opportunities for social interaction. Utilization of current and new partnering relationships will be used to increase participation by students from underrepresented groups. This program is supported by the Division of Engineering Education and Centers of the National Science Foundation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Micro and nanofabrication of solid-state devices are critical components of modern economic development, and diverse leadership in research on devices for electronics, photonics, and magnetics applications is a key to sustained US economic competitiveness. Yet many undergraduate students have limited exposure to advanced topics in this field which are needed to drive the semiconductor and photonics industries. The Summer Undergraduate Research Experience in Solid-State Devices for Electronics, Photonics, and Magnetics Technology (the "SURE" program) provided undergraduate students with an in-depth ten-week directed research experience focused on this critical area of engineering and science.  It also provided professional development seminars and workshops that helped to prepare students for careers as professional engineers and scientists.

 

The SURE program ran from 2013 through 2016, providing 10 week summer research experiences.  A total of 40 students from around the country participated in this summer research program during its four-year duration.  Each student was assigned to a faculty member at Clemson University who guided them through various projects related to solid-state devices.  Graduate students working under the faculty also mentored the students and helped them with their projects in the lab.  Each participant explored an important open problem of current research interest using advanced methods of experimentation, analysis, and modeling.  Formal lectures, directed reading, discussion, and demonstration formed the basis for independent study and research by each student.  The program's rigorous scientific emphasis developed analytical and experimental skills based on a solid grounding in topic-specific concepts.  Our materials-to-devices paradigm for research provided a broad perspective to the participating students both theoretically and experimentally.  The faculty mentors involved in the REU have been highly successful in conducting independent, collaborative interdisciplinary research in diverse but interrelated areas ranging from fundamental materials and physics to functional devices, circuits, and systems.  The program utilized the superb laboratory facilities developed by the faculty cohort as well as those administered by Clemson University. 

 

            The SURE program was centered on the philosophy of developing tomorrow's leaders in academic and industrial research on solid-state device technology.  We focused on the selection of highly talented participants, and worked hard to instill in them a strong interest in pursuing a Ph.D. and a research-oriented career.  In preparation for this role, the program was structured to strengthen the participants' professional written and oral communication skills and enhance their understanding of the ethical and societal context within which engineering research is performed.  Thus we held multiple writing workshops and oral communications workshops to foster these skills.  Each student prepared a written technical paper, gave an oral presentation, and presented a poster describing their research project and the results.  The impact of this experience contributed significantly to their skill set in preparation for future studies and careers.

 

            To foster a diversified workforce of the future, we coordinated our recruitment efforts with Clemson’s PEER (Programs for Education Enrichment and Retention) and WISE (Women In Science and Engineering) programs to ensure a diverse group of students, in particular minority and female, were afforded access and attraction to our REU program.  Currently established relationships between our faculty and minority-serving institutions further enhanced diversity in the program.  These collaborations and agreements provided us with excellent mechanisms to recruit female and minority students from institutions where STEM research opportunities are limited, which should also enhance research capabilities within these other institutions. 

 

            The outcomes of this program were encouraging.  The statistics from the first three years are presented, since the 4th year was a reduced program partially funded by Clemson University.

Participant Demographics

Total participants funded by this program (1st Three Years):  31

Clemson undergraduates:  7 (23%)        Non-Clemson:  24         (77%)

Male:   19         (61%)                              Female: 12        (39%)

White, non-Hispanic:  22  (71%)             Asian, non-Hispanic:    3 (10%)

African American:            4  (13%)          Hispanic:       2 (6%)

Total from underrepresented groups:     17  (55%)

 

To date, over 85% of the participants are in graduate school or are applying to graduate schools.  Most of the other students have indicated that they eventually plan to pursue graduate studies and research careers.

 

So it is clear that the SURE program has succeeded in preparing a significant number of students, many from underrepresented groups, for advanced education in engineering and science disciplines as well as prepared them for their future careers.  Increasing the number of diverse US citizens entering STEM fields is not only beneficial to the individual students, but to the broader society as well.
